title: Hayes Breaks Down Telling Jury He Hasn’t ‘Done Anything’ Wrong
text:
Former UBS Group AG trader Tom Hayes broke down in tears on the witness stand as he explained that he didn’t think he’d done anything wrong.
Hayes, who is charged with conspiring to manipulate Libor, became increasingly emotional after his lawyer asked him to explain why he had characterized his behavior as “dishonest” in an interview with prosecutors. Hayes said he felt compelled to exaggerate his role in order to be charged in the U.K. and avoid extradition to the U.S.
“I’m trying to give the answer I needed to give,” Hayes said with his wife and family looking on from the public gallery in a London courtroom. I wanted to say “I don’t think I’ve done anything” wrong.
The 35-year-old Hayes has been testifying this week at his trial where he has pleaded not guilty to eight counts of conspiracy to manipulate the London interbank offered rate, the benchmark used to value more than $350 trillion of loans and securities. Each count carries as much as 10 years in prison.
Prosecutors say Hayes bullied and cajoled fellow traders and brokers to move benchmark rates to make his positions more profitable. Hayes’s lawyers say the practice was widespread.
